section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter governs the requirements for a commercial air ambulance service.

para.text: To be licensed as a commercial care air ambulance service, a commercial air ambulance service shall comply with the requirements of this chapter in addition to the other applicable requirements of this subtitle.
An applicant for a commercial air ambulance service license shall submit an application to SOCALR on the required form.
An applicant for a commercial air ambulance service license shall:
Be accredited by CAMTS; or
If ineligible to apply for CAMTS accreditation, because it has been in service for less than 1 year:
Submit to SOCALR a CAMTS consultation report indicating compliance with the CAMTS standards; and
Apply for and receive full CAMTS accreditation within 18 months of being licensed by SOCALR.
A licensed commercial air ambulance service shall notify SOCALR within 24 hours of any change in CAMTS accreditation status and the reason for the change.
A licensed commercial air ambulance service may provide ALS, critical care, or neonatal transport service, or any combination of these, if:
The equipment and personnel requirements of this subtitle are met for the specific type of transport;
The submitted service license application includes the information required, demonstrating compliance for the specific type of transport; and
The service is accredited by CAMTS at that level.
A licensed commercial air ambulance service may not provide services with an unlicensed air ambulance unless:
The unlicensed air ambulance is used as a temporary replacement for a licensed air ambulance that is out of service for routine maintenance or repair;
The temporary replacement air ambulance meets all FAA requirements;
The temporary replacement air ambulance has all required staffing and equipment; and
It has notified SOCALR of the use of the replacement air ambulance and provided the following information:
The unit designation number assigned for operational purposes;
The FAA registration number; and
The make, model, and year of manufacture.
A licensed commercial air ambulance service that provides services with an unlicensed air ambulance shall notify SOCALR when the licensed air ambulance is returned to service.

section.heading: Additional Personnel Requirements for Commercial Air Ambulance Services.
section.text: A commercial air ambulance shall be staffed by:

para.text: A pilot who meets the requirements of licensure established by the Federal Aviation Administration 14 CFR Parts 61, 67, and 135; and
At least two additional individuals who meet or exceed the requirements for CAMTS accreditation at the level which the service is providing.

section.heading: Additional Equipment Requirements for Air Ambulances.

para.text: Each air ambulance shall carry sufficient equipment and supplies listed in COMAR 30.09.10—13 to assure:
The ability to carry out all procedures in the Maryland Medical Protocols for EMS Providers; and
That when transporting specialty care patients, the additional equipment necessary to care for the patient being transported is available;
A list of medical equipment and supplies will be provided to SOCALR with the licensing application.
All medical, communications, and associated equipment on-board:
If routinely carried, shall be EMI certified for air operations; or
If not routinely used, shall be approved by the pilot.

section.heading: Operational Requirements for Air Ambulance Services.

para.text: Pilots of rotary wing air ambulances shall remain with the aircraft when the aircraft is occupying a hospital helipad with room for landing a single aircraft.
SYSCOM shall coordinate the landing sequence of multiple emergency medical services aircraft in consultation with the pilots-in-command based on patient priority.
Commercial air ambulance services shall:
Comply with the requirements of COMAR 30.07; and
Keep SYSCOM apprised of the location of their air ambulance at all times while the aircraft is in Maryland or in geographic proximity to the Maryland border in a contiguous state.
